ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Managing dense lectures, reading scientific papers
I really liked this course. I learned about modern techniques and biology like COVID-19 and sequencing.
Reviewed some concepts of previous biology courses but for the purpose of applying them to biotechnology. Students learned methods and concepts of different technologies.
I gained knowledge of modern biotechnological advancements/biologics/small molecule drugs, current information regarding COVID-19 vaccines and therapeutics, research on Alzheimer's Disease and more!
I learned a lot about biotechnology from various perspectives

I learned about the development of biotechnology, advances that are used to treat diseases and help the environment and the future directions of the field. We heard from many lecturers who covered fields from immunology/virology, small drugs/molecules, and climate change.

I learned a lot of extremely useful information in this class. I learned about how emerging biotechnologies are funded, how to convince someone that the Covid vaccine is safe and that climate change is human-influenced, and more.
I learned a lot about the variety of hot topics in the bioscience sector.
Great course to learn the basics of biotechnology and how to use it to begin a company.
So much. More than any other class regarding science and the field
Biotech industry, biotech start ups, investment banking, the business side of bio developments, etc.
Learned about a range of topics in biotechnology including sequencing, COVID-19 and RNA technology, as well as other building a biotech company and IP law.
I learned a lot about how to begin a BioTech company and what factors go into starting one. I also learned a fair range of biotechnical practices/disciplines I wasn't familiar with before!
Biotech and its applications

Cancer therapeutics, antibody therapies, plant biotech (three lectures on this!),  biology of Alzheimer's disease and therapeutic solutions, COVID-19 biology, vaccines and therapeutics, bioremediation, DNA sequencing, synthesis and editing technology, nucleic acid technology, venture capital firms in biotech,  patent law, etc
How to read scientific papers with biotech applications, some history about biotech, but mostly memorization of loosely connected topics related to biotechnology
Very broad knowledge of biotechnology with deep dives into specific areas of the professors specialties. Also gained knowledge of the business and legal side of biotech.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It's a lot of different professors teaching, so not much continuity

Strengths - topics are amazing, it's extremely interesting and well taught

Weakness - A bit disorganized, we never got an announcement about the final exam, section was also sometimes unproductive

Strengths: some of the material could be a bit dense but the usage of multiple professors and guest lecturers made the material very interesting
Weaknesses: Personally, it often felt like lecture was very different from discussion sections so it felt like I had to prepare for 2 different classes every week.
Strengths include informative and real-world lectures on current topics, especially, COVID-19 as well as guest lecturers pertaining to venture capital and patent law.
Because different professors sometimes information gets repeated, but overall a great MCDB upper-level course
I appreciated the many guest lecturers. They each had their own unique connection to the fields that they were teaching so I appreciated their enthusiasm and dedication.
This class does not need a section.
Great course and they had so many different lecturers that it kept everything fresh.
No weaknesses

Strengths: great content, professors showed interest in own fields
Weaknesses: multiple profs and teaching styles could be confusing to adapt to at times especially during evaluations

Strengths: this was an awesome course 
Improvement: the tests should have been open note given the online no-proctoring format

The course covers a wide range of topics and provides a great introduction to current areas in biotechnology. I particularly loved how we also we able to hear from guest speakers and about the industry side in terms of running a company. Th course could be improved by spending a little bit more time on some of the topics that we only covered for one week.
I would say the grading on the quizzes is a bit harsh; if it was a better reflection of one's performance in the class, this would be a great MCDB course.

Quizzes should not be so short (time-wise and number of questions); give us time to display what we really learned so that we are not just racing against the clock! Also if you forget one small thing from lecture and it shows up on the quiz you are basically done for because the quizzes are only two questions. Also many of the first lectures in the class were very introductory and gave very broad overviews of basic concepts in biotech; these lectures could have been condensed and more course content could have been devoted to more specific topics.
Strength is definitely the guest speakers; Prof. Crews does a great job of curating great speakers (this year, we had people from venture capital, IP law, and biotech/pharma start-ups.)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recorded lectures very helpful
Virtual engagement was high during discussion section and professors allowed time at the end of class for students to ask questions.
The option to watch lectures later/record them

The sections were very helpful. The papers that we read provided context for the material that we provided in lecture and the field's future directions. I feel as though my ability to read and understand scientific papers has greatly improved.
They were very accommodating by recording the lectures but also providing them as live.
Great

Success: recording the lectures! 
Improvements: having the quizzes/exams being open note

Live lectures and discussion sections worked very well. Discussion provided a great opportunity to examine areas talked about in class through papers. Furthermore, discussions allowed for interactions with other students in the class.
Section was very interactive
Recording live lectures! This allowed me to take this course with another class that met at the same time.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I personally learned a lot!! Three lectures were adapted to teach us entirely about COVID-19, which was amazing.
Definitely, I loved the topics in this class
Yes, this is a great elective for MCDB.
Yes, I highly recommend this course, as the topics covered are relevant to the current biotech and entrepreneurial climate and I thoroughly enjoyed the guest lectures.
I strongly recommend this course to every MCDB major.
I would
Yes! The course covers lots of disciplines within the realm of biotechnology so you are likely to find something that you find interesting and engaging.

Yes, I think this class is chock-full of incredibly interesting and important information. This is the first MCDB class where I learned information that can actually help me outside of the lab. I think all MCDB majors should take this class.
Yes! You learn a lot and it's very chill. Watch the lectures, review the slides a few times before the quizzes and tests and you'll be golden.
Absolutely! The techniques learned are critical for people who want to pursue biotechnology.
Yes of course. Best class
Absolutely! Loved this class! Its pretty easy, especially if you have already taken other bio classes because the concepts such as crispr/cas9 and transgenesis wont be entirely new

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course! It is great for better understanding the biotechnology industry. It is also an incredible way to apply knowledge from other biology classes and see how it can be used in a wide range of fields.
Sure. If you are interested in Biotechnology, there isn't a better course for it.
Yes
Yes, if you are looking for an easy upper-level MCDB course (350+); very interesting material! All real-world applications of the biology concepts we learn in class.
Yes, solid 350+ elective for MCDB. Content is not difficult, just requires some cramming before quizzes and exams.

This is an excellent class for anyone interested in any area of biotechnology pharma, devices, agriculture, stem cell therapy, etc. The professors were all very engaging and gave great overviews and in-depth looks into their specialties.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lectures
Live virtual, recorded lecture, section
Live virtual lecture and live virtual discussion section
Recorded and live virtual lecture
I reviewed with the recorded lectures.
The lectures were given live but were also recorded and posted for students to view afterwards.
Sometimes they offered in person lectures.
Section
Recorded and live
Live Discussion Sections
All live lectures were recorded and posted to Canvas.
Mix of recorded and live virtual lectures; guest speakers were live, and different professors chose to do either recorded or live lectures.
live section
